docs.title: Base de datos
docs.text:
Una tabla en MySQL es una estructura dentro de una base de datos que organiza los datos en filas y columnas, como si fuera una hoja de cálculo.

Cada fila (row) representa un registro individual, y cada columna (column) representa un campo de dato

Ejemplo: Una tabla alumnos podría tener columnas como id, nombre, edad, correo, etc., y cada fila representa un alumno distinto.

docs.title: Ejemplo de tabla en SQL
docs.text: ```sql title="Crear tabla alumnos" CREATE TABLE alumnos ( id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY, nombre VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL, edad INT, correo VARCHAR(100) UNIQUE );

docs.title: ☠️ Threats and Vulnerabilities
docs.text:
Threat: harm, lost, damage or compromise info or system

Threat Descripción Natural Disasters Harm, damage Cyber-attacks harm, damage Data Integrity breaches harm, damage Disclosure of confidential information harm. damage

Vulnerability: Any weakness in the system design or implementation They come from internal factors

  • Software bugs
  • Misconfigured software
  • Improperly protected network devices
  • Missing security patches
  • Lack of physical security

but it can be prevent from being exploited

  • Mitigating
  • Transferring, avoiding or accepting the risk (becomes a risk management decision)

Remember Neme: If I have:

  • Threat + No vulnerability = No Risk
  • Vulnerability + No threat = No Risk

Risk Management: Finding different ways to minimize the likelihood (probabilitie) of an outcome occurring and achieve the desired outcomes.

Cybersecurity is the continuity of services to the end users, maintaining the overall security of the systems and protect the organization from data breaches by minimizing the vulnerabilities or mitigating the risk it this impact.

docs.title: Confidentiality
docs.text:
Protect the information from unauthorized access and disclosure (Could be an individual, entity or process).

Keeping information secret and safe from prying eyes, only access who they need to access.

3 main reasons of Confidentiality

  1. Protect personal privacy
  2. Maintain a business advantage
  3. Achieve regulatory compliance (PII, PHI, Various types of financial data
  4. PII: Personal identifiable information, PHI: Protected health info.

How to maintain the Confidentiality

  1. Encryption
  2. Access Controls
  3. Data Masking
  4. Physical Security Measures
  5. Training and awareness

docs.title: 🔐 Integrity Overview
docs.text: Protects data from unauthorized changes to maintain accuracy.

docs.title: ✅ Methods to Maintain Integrity
docs.text: Method Details Example 🔢 Hashing Converts data into a fixed-size value to detect unauthorized changes. Comparing hash values before and after file transfer. ✍️ Digital Signatures Ensure both the integrity and authenticity of data. Signing a PDF to confirm authorship and prevent tampering. ✔️ Checksums Used to verify data integrity during transmission. Verifying downloaded software with provided checksum value. 🔐 Access Controls Only authorized users can modify data, reducing risks of tampering. Only HR can update employee salary records. 📋 Regular Audits Systematically review logs and changes; identify unauthorized modifications quickly. Reviewing system logs weekly to detect unauthorized changes.

docs.title: 📶 Availability Overview
docs.text:
Ensures that information, systems, and resources are accessible and operational when needed by authorized users. | Employees can access internal systems 24/7 without downtime. |

🔎 Why Availability Matters

Benefit Description Example Business Continuity Keeps operations running during failures A backup server activates instantly after the main one fails. Customer Trust Maintains reliable services Users trust online banking due to constant service uptime. Organization's Reputation Avoids negative impact due to outages A retail site remains online during high-traffic holiday sales.

🔁 Redundancy Strategies:

To overcome the challenges associated with maintaining availability, the best strategy is to use redundancy in the systems and network designs.

Redundancy Type Description Example Redundancy Duplication of critical components or functions to enhance reliability. Having a backup internet connection and server for critical services. Server Redundancy Uses multiple servers in a load-balanced or failover configuration to maintain service availability. If one server crashes, others continue handling user traffic. Data Redundancy Stores data in multiple locations to prevent loss or access failure. Cloud storage syncing data across different regions. Network Redundancy Uses multiple network paths to ensure data delivery if one route fails. Internet reroutes through a backup ISP line if the main one is down. Power Redundancy Uses backup power sources like UPS or generators to avoid power-related downtime. Data center switches to generator during a city-wide blackout.

docs.title: 🔏 Non-repudiation
docs.text: Aspect Description Definition Ensures undeniable proof that participants cannot deny their involvement in digital actions. Importance - Confirms authenticity of digital transactions- Ensures integrity of communications- Provides accountability in digital processes

docs.title: ✍️ Digital Signatures
docs.text:
Aspect Description Definition Unique to each user; created by hashing a message and encrypting it with the user's private key using asymmetric encryption. Purpose Verify authenticity and integrity of digital communications.

○ Importance of Non-repudiation: ✔️ To confirm the authenticity of digital transactions ✔️ To ensure the integrity of critical communications ✔️ To provide accountability in digital processes

docs.title: 🔐Authentication
docs.text:
Verifies the identity of individuals or entities in a communication or transaction

🔐 5 Authentication Methods Overview

Authentication Method Description Example Authentication (General) Ensures individuals or entities are who they claim to be during a communication or transaction. Logging into a secure website with a password. Something You Know (Knowledge) Relies on information that a user can recall. Passwords, PINs, or security questions. Something You Have (Possession) Relies on presenting a physical item to authenticate. Security token, smart card, or a mobile authenticator app. Something You Are (Inherence) Uses unique physical or behavioral traits of a person. Fingerprint, face scan, or retina scan. Something You Do (Action) Depends on a user’s unique behavior or action. Typing rhythm, voice recognition. Somewhere You Are (Location) Uses the user's geographic location as a factor in authentication. Logging in only when located at the office or within a country.

○ Authentication is critical to understand because of the following:

  • ✅ To prevent unauthorized access
  • 🔒 To protect user data and privacy
  • 👤 To ensure that resources are accessed by valid users only

docs.title: 🔑 Authorization
docs.text:
Pertains to the permissions and privileges granted to users or entities after they have been authenticated.

○ Authorization mechanisms are important to help us with the following: - 🔒 To protect sensitive data - 🛡️ To maintain the system integrity in our organizations - ⚙️ To create a more streamlined user experience

docs.title: 📊 Accounting
docs.text:
Tracks and records all user activities during communication or transactions.

✅ The organization should use a robust accounting system creating the following process:

Topic Description Example Audit Trail Chronological record to trace changes or unauthorized access. Reviewing logs after a security breach. Regulatory Compliance Maintains records to meet legal and industry standards. Providing logs during a compliance audit. Forensic Analysis Helps understand incidents to prevent recurrence. Analyzing event logs after a cyberattack. Resource Optimization Tracks usage to improve system performance and cost-efficiency. Monitoring bandwidth to reduce overuse. User Accountability Ensures user actions are logged to deter misuse. Tracking employee activity on critical systems. Technology Purpose Example Syslog Servers Aggregate logs from devices for analysis. Central log server collecting firewall logs. Network Analysis Tools Capture and analyze network traffic. Monitoring suspicious traffic on a corporate LAN. SIEM Systems Real-time security alert analysis. Detecting unusual login attempts immediately.

docs.title: 🔒 Security Controls Categories
docs.text:
Multifaceted layers of protection to form a security posture. Main function to protect Confidentiality, Integrity and Availability

Categories Descripción Technical Controls HW and SW implemented to manage and reduce risk (Firewalls, Encryption, Intrusion Detection Systems) Managerial Controls or Administrative Controls Strategic planning and governance side of security align to the business goal and risk tolerance (conduct a risk assessments, security policies, training programs, incident response strategies for make decision and keep informed the organization in the same security page) Operational Controls Procedures and measures designed to protect data on a day to day basis most of them governed by internal processes and human actions (change the passwd, backup procedures, account reviews, user training programs). this can be ongoing process to ensure the security. Physical Controls Tangible, real-world measures taken to protect assets: digital and non-digital. (Shredding of sensitive documents, Security guards, Locking doors).

docs.title: 🛡️ Security Control Types
docs.text:
This will depend of the specific threat o vulnerability to address

Types Objective Description Preventive Controls proactive measures, build foundation proactive measures implemented to thwart potential security threats or breaches before the inciden occur (firewall). Deterrent Controls discourage threats- warnings Aim to discourage potential attackers by making the effort seem less appealing or more challenging. **( Warning Signs, banners to indicate the monitoring is occurring) Detective Controls detection and notification, watchful eye Monitor and alert to malicious activities as the occur or shortly thereafter. ** (Network: IDS (Intrusion-Detection-System).** Corrective Controls jumping in emergencies Mitigate any potential damage and restore the system to their normal state.*(mitigate the vulnerabilities). Compensating Controls backups and mitigations Alternative measure implemented when primary security controls are not feasible or effective (plan b of security)example: in a test online: 3 layers of security network: my phone, cable dsl, wifi)** Directive Controls guide the entire process Policy or documentation that set the standards for behavior in the organization. (policy how employs use company-owned IT assets).

docs.title: 🔐 Zero Trust:  Never trust, always verify...
docs.text:
This mean we can not just trust to the network perimeter to protect the system as a main line of defense, with deperimeterization (common in cloud and remote work and adoption of new technologies)we are put a lot or risk into the organization that is why we need to focus on: strong authentication, data encryption access controls per user/devices, zero trust architecture.

Zero Trust demands verify for every device, user and transaction within the network, regardless of its origin (it doesn't mater where it comes from: inside or outside the network.

Types Objective Description Control Plane is the brain (making decisions) Adaptive Identity, threat scope reduction, policy-driven access control, secured zones with Policy Engine and Policy Administrator. Data Plane is the hands (doing the work) Subject/System and Policy Enforcement Point

📌 Control Plane

Control Plane Description Control Plane responsible for defining, managing, and enforcing the policies related to user and system access. Adaptive Identity validation into account user behavior, device, location and more. Threat scope reduction Limit he access only for the need work tasks, avoid risk and compromise credentials. Policy-driven access control Enforce user access policies based on their roles and responsibilities. Secured zones Isolated environments within a network that are designed to house sensitive data.

Control Plane uses: Policy Engine and Policy Administrator to makes security decisions.

Decision-making and enforcement What it does How it works Example Question? Policy Engine Makes decisions based on policies Evaluates context like user identity, device health, location, and request type. Decides if a user with a healthy laptop and MFA can access a sensitive app. Should this request be allowed? Policy Administrator Enforces the decision from the Policy Engine. Connects to the Policy Enforcement Point (PEP) to allow or block traffic. Sends an “allow” command to the firewall or gateway to permit access. Apply the Policy Engine’s decision

The Policy Enforcement Point (PEP) is the security gateway or system that executes the decision: allow, block, or limit user/device access.

🔁 Flow Summary: 1. User makes a request. 2. Policy Engine evaluates based on policies 3. Policy Administrator applies the decision via the Policy Enforcement Point (PEP).

📌 Data Plane

Component What it Does How it Works Example Subject/System Verify the authenticity of the subject or system. The user, device, or application requesting access to resources. Sends access requests and presents credentials or context to the system. An employee’s laptop trying to access a corporate app. Policy Enforcement Point (PEP) Enforces access control decisions by allowing or blocking data flow. Acts as a gateway or proxy that checks with the Control Plane before permitting access. Firewall, secure proxy, or cloud access gateway controlling traffic to an app.

docs.title: ⚠️ Gap Analysis
docs.text:
Is the process used to compare the current state of a process, system, or performance against a desired future state. It helps identify the "gaps" or differences that need to be addressed to achieve the goals.

Example: A company wants to improve its cybersecurity posture. The current state shows basic firewall protection, but the desired state includes advanced threat detection and response capabilities. The gap analysis reveals missing tools and processes that must be implemented to reach the desired security level.

Current State Desired State Identified Gap Basic firewall protection Advanced threat detection & response Lack of security monitoring tools Manual patch management Automated patch deployment Need for automation in updates Limited employee training Regular security awareness training Insufficient user education

docs.title: 🔍 Scanning and Tools
docs.text: Tool/Term Short Definition Example Vulnerability Management The ongoing process of identifying, assessing, prioritizing, and remediating security weaknesses. Regularly scanning systems to find and fix software bugs. CVE Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures; unique ID for vulnerabilities. CVE-2023-12345 identifying a specific software flaw. CVSS Common Vulnerability Scoring System; rates severity of vulnerabilities. CVSS score 9.8 indicating a critical vulnerability. CWE Common Weakness Enumeration; categorizes types of software weaknesses. CWE-79 refers to Cross-Site Scripting (XSS). OWASP Open Web Application Security Project; provides web app security guidelines. OWASP Top 10 listing critical web security risks.

docs.title: 🔄 Change Management
docs.text: Term Short Definition Example Change Any addition, modification, or removal of anything that could affect IT services. Upgrading the company’s email server software. Problem Underlying cause of one or more incidents affecting services. Repeated server crashes traced back to faulty software. Incident Unplanned interruption or reduction in quality of an IT service. Network outage causing loss of connectivity for users. Emergency Change Management Fast-tracked change process to address critical issues urgently. Patching a critical security vulnerability immediately. RCA (Root Cause Analysis) Process to identify the fundamental cause of a problem or incident. Investigating why a database failure occurred and fixing it.

docs.title: 🌅 Sunset Process
docs.text: Term Short Definition Example Offboarding App Process of decommissioning an application from active use. Retiring an old HR system and migrating users to a new one. Remove Data Securely deleting all data related to the decommissioned app. Wiping user records and logs from the old app database. Remove Infra Shutting down and dismantling infrastructure supporting the app. Deleting virtual servers and storage used by the retired app.

docs.title: 🗂️ Filesystem Hierarchy Standard (FHS)
docs.text: Directory Description Example /boot Contains boot loader files /boot/grub/grub.cfg /proc Virtual filesystem with process and system info /proc/cpuinfo /sys Interface to the kernel /sys/class/net/eth0 /var Variable data like logs and spool files /var/log/syslog /usr User utilities and applications /usr/bin/python3 /lib Essential shared libraries /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 /dev Device files /dev/sda1 /etc System configuration files /etc/hosts /opt Optional/add-on software packages /opt/google/chrome/ /bin Essential user command binaries /bin/ls /sbin Essential system binaries /sbin/reboot /home User home directories /home/viviana /media Mount point for removable media /media/usb /mnt Temporary mount point /mnt/external_drive /root Home directory for root user /root/.bashrc /tmp Temporary files /tmp/install.log

docs.title: 💾 Basic boot process components
docs.text: Component Description Example BIOS (Basic Input/Output System) Legacy firmware that initializes hardware and starts the bootloader Accessed by pressing F2 or Del during startup UEFI (Unified Extensible Firmware Interface) Modern firmware replacing BIOS, with more features and faster booting Accessed via F12 or Esc on newer systems mkinitrd Creates an initial RAM disk image for booting mkinitrd /boot/initrd.img-$(uname -r) grub2-install Installs the GRUB2 bootloader to a device grub2-install /dev/sda grub2-mkconfig Generates a new GRUB2 configuration file grub2-mkconfig -o /boot/grub2/grub.cfg grub2-update Updates GRUB2 with the latest kernel (alias for grub2-mkconfig on some systems) grub2-update dracut Tool to generate initramfs (initial RAM filesystem) dracut -f initrd.img Initial RAM disk used during early boot /boot/initrd.img-5.15.0 vmlinuz Compressed Linux kernel executable /boot/vmlinuz-5.15.0 GRUB2 (Grand Unified Bootloader v2) Bootloader that loads and transfers control to the Linux kernel /boot/grub2/grub.cfg PXE (Preboot Execution Environment) Boots system from a network server Booting diskless workstations using PXE server USB Boot Boots system from a USB flash drive Installing Linux from /dev/sdb1 ISO Boot Boots system from an ISO image Booting from ubuntu.iso using virtual machine or USB

docs.title: 🛠️ Basic package compilation
docs.text: Step Description Example ./configure Prepares the build environment by checking system dependencies and generating Makefiles ./configure --prefix=/usr/local make Compiles the source code into executable binaries based on the Makefile make make install Installs the compiled binaries and other files to the system (requires root) sudo make install

docs.title: 💻 Storage concepts
docs.text: Concept Description Example File Storage Stores data as a hierarchy of files and folders NFS, SMB/CIFS Block Storage Stores data in fixed-size blocks for performance and flexibility iSCSI, SAN Object Storage Stores data as objects with metadata and unique IDs Amazon S3, OpenStack Swift MBR (Master Boot Record) Legacy partitioning scheme, supports up to 4 primary partitions /dev/sda1 using MBR GPT (GUID Partition Table) Modern partitioning scheme, supports large disks and more partitions /dev/sda1 using GPT FUSE (Filesystem in Userspace) Allows non-privileged users to create and mount their own filesystems sshfs, encfs RAID - Striping (RAID 0) Splits data across multiple disks for speed, no redundancy 2 disks striped for performance RAID - Mirroring (RAID 1) Duplicates data across two or more disks for redundancy 2 mirrored drives for high availability RAID - Parity (RAID 5/6) Uses parity information for fault tolerance with efficient storage 3+ disks with 1 disk of space used for parity ---

docs.title: 🖥️ Listing hardware information
docs.text:
Command Description Example Usage Example Output (Shortened) lspci Lists all PCI devices (graphics cards, network cards, etc) lspci 00:1f.2 SATA controller: Intel Corporation ... lsusb Lists all USB devices connected to the system lsusb Bus 002 Device 003: ID 0bda:5411 Realtek ... dmidecode Displays hardware information from the system BIOS sudo dmidecode -t system Manufacturer: Dell Inc.\nProduct Name: XPS 15 ...

## 📌 Tips:

  • Run dmidecode with sudo to avoid permission issues.
  • Use flags like -t memory, -t processor, or -t system with dmidecode to get specific hardware information.
  • These tools are valuable for:
    • Hardware inventory 📋
    • Troubleshooting 🐞
    • Audit reports 📑

docs.title: 📑 Manage files and directories
docs.text:
📁 File Editing

Command Description Example sed Stream editor for filtering and transforming text sed 's/error/ok/g' file.txt awk Pattern scanning and processing language awk '{print $1}' file.txt printf Formats and prints data printf "Name: %s\n" "$USER" nano Terminal-based text editor nano file.txt vi(m) Advanced text editor in Unix/Linux systems vim file.txt

📦 File Compression, Archiving, and Backup

Command Description Example gzip Compresses files using GNU zip gzip file.txt bzip2 Compresses files using Burrows-Wheeler algorithm bzip2 file.txt zip Packs and compresses files into .zip archive zip archive.zip file1 file2 tar Archives files without compression tar -cvf archive.tar folder/ xz Compresses files with LZMA2 algorithm xz file.txt cpio Copies files to/from archives find . -type f dd Copies/converts files at byte level; used for backups dd if=/dev/sda of=/backup.img bs=4M

🧾 File Metadata

Command Description Example stat Displays detailed info about a file stat file.txt file Identifies the file type file image.png

🔗 Soft and Hard Links

Command Description Example ln -s Creates symbolic (soft) link ln -s /source/file link.txt ln Creates hard link ln /source/file link.txt

🌐 Copying Files Between Systems

Command Description Example rsync Syncs files/directories efficiently over network rsync -av folder/ user@host:/backup/ scp Securely copies files over SSH scp file.txt user@host:/remote/dir nc Transfers data using Netcat nc -l -p 1234 > received.txt (listener side)

📂 File and Directory Operations

Command Description Example mv Move or rename files/directories mv old.txt new.txt cp Copy files/directories cp file.txt /tmp/ mkdir Create new directory mkdir new_folder rmdir Remove empty directory rmdir empty_folder ls List files in directory ls -l pwd Show current directory pwd rm Delete file or directory rm file.txt cd Change current directory cd /var/log . Current directory ./script.sh .. Parent directory cd .. ~ Home directory cd ~ tree Shows tree view of directory tree cat Show file contents cat file.txt touch Create file or update timestamp touch newfile.txt

docs.title: 👤 implement identity management
docs.text:
👥 Account Creation and Deletion Utilities

Command Description Example useradd Create a new user account sudo useradd -m -s /bin/bash username groupadd Create a new user group sudo groupadd developers userdel Delete a user account sudo userdel -r username groupdel Delete a user group sudo groupdel developers usermod Modify user account settings sudo usermod -aG sudo username groupmod Modify group details sudo groupmod -n newgroupname oldgroupname id Show user ID and group IDs id username who Show who is logged in who w Show who is logged in with details w 
Ex: Vpena:x:1001:1001:Viviana Pena /home/Vpena/bin/bash
    Vpena: nombre del usuario
    X: contraseña encriptada (etc/shadow)
    1001: UID
    1001: GID
    Viviana Pena: descripción
    /home/Vpena: carpeta personal
    /bin/bash: shell predeterminado

🐚 Default Shell

Item Description Example Default shell Shell assigned to user on login Check default shell: grep username /etc/passwd

⚙️ Configuration Files

File Purpose Example /etc/passwd User account info, including UID, shell cat /etc/passwd /etc/group Group account info cat /etc/group /etc/shadow Encrypted passwords and aging info sudo cat /etc/shadow /etc/profile System-wide environment variables and startup scripts cat /etc/profile /etc/skel Template files copied to new user's home directory Files copied when useradd -m is run .bash_profile User-specific login shell initialization file ~/.bash_profile .bashrc User-specific interactive shell configuration ~/.bashrc

🔐 Account Management Commands

Command Description Example passwd Change user password passwd username chage Modify password expiry and aging sudo chage -l username pam_tally2 Show and manage failed login attempts pam_tally2 --user=username faillock Lock/unlock user accounts on failure faillock --user=username --reset /etc/login.defs Default user account settings and policies cat /etc/login.defs

👥 User Classes

Symbol Class Description Example u user File owner chmod u+x file.sh adds execute to user g group Users in the file’s group chmod g-w file.txt removes write o others All other users chmod o= file.txt removes all perms a all All: user + group + others chmod a+r file.txt adds read to all

🔢 Numeric Mode

Number Permissions Description Example 0 --- No permissions chmod 000 file.txt 1 --x Execute only 2 -w- Write only 3 -wx Write and execute 4 r-- Read only 5 r-x Read and execute 6 rw- Read and write 7 rwx Full permissions chmod 755 script.sh

docs.title: 🔓 Apply the appropriate access controls
docs.text:
🗂️ File Permissions

Concept Description Example Command or Use ACL Extended file permissions beyond owner/group/others setfacl -m u:john:rw file.txt SUID Executes file with the owner’s privileges chmod u+s /path/to/file SGID Executes file with the group’s privileges chmod g+s /path/to/file Sticky Bit Restricts file deletion to owner in shared directories chmod +t /tmp

🛠️ File Permission Utilities

Command Description Example chown Change file owner chown user:group file.txt chmod Change file mode (permissions) chmod 755 script.sh umask Set default permissions umask 022 chgrp Change group ownership chgrp staff file.txt ls List files (with permissions using -l) ls -l getfacl View ACLs getfacl file.txt setfacl Set ACLs setfacl -m g:developers:rwx file.txt setenforce Change SELinux state setenforce 1 getenforce Show SELinux current mode getenforce chcon Change SELinux context chcon -t httpd_sys_content_t index.html restorecon Restore default SELinux context restorecon -Rv /var/www/html semanage Manage SELinux policy components semanage fcontext -a -t httpd_sys_content_t '/web(/.*)?' audit2allow Generate SELinux policy from audit logs audit2allow -w -a

🔐 SELinux Concepts

Concept Description Example Command or Use Context permissions File security context (user, role, type, level) ls -Z /var/www/html Labels Used by SELinux to enforce policies chcon -t httpd_sys_content_t file.html Autorelabel Relabels file system context on reboot touch /.autorelabel && reboot

⚙️ SELinux System Booleans

Boolean Setting Description Example Command setsebool Temporarily or persistently set bool setsebool -P httpd_can_network_connect 1 getsebool Show current boolean values getsebool -a

🔄 SELinux States

State Description Example Command Enforcing SELinux actively enforces policies setenforce 1 Permissive Logs actions that would be denied setenforce 0 Disabled SELinux is turned off Set in /etc/selinux/config

🛡️ SELinux Policy Types

Policy Type Description Where It's Used Targeted Protects specific targeted processes Default on most distributions Minimum Minimal protection policy Rare; more granular configuration

🛡️ AppArmor

Command Description Example chown Change file owner chown user:group file.txt chmod Change file mode (permissions) chmod 755 script.sh umask Set default permissions umask 022 chgrp Change group ownership chgrp staff file.txt ls List files (with permissions using -l) ls -l getfacl View ACLs getfacl file.txt setfacl Set ACLs setfacl -m g:developers:rwx file.txt setenforce Change SELinux state setenforce 1 getenforce Show SELinux current mode getenforce chcon Change SELinux context chcon -t httpd_sys_content_t index.html restorecon Restore default SELinux context restorecon -Rv /var/www/html semanage Manage SELinux policy components semanage fcontext -a -t httpd_sys_content_t '/web(/.*)?' audit2allow Generate SELinux policy from audit logs audit2allow -w -a

docs.title: ⚙️ Configure and use the appropriate processes and services
docs.text:
⚙️ System Services

Command Description Example systemctl stop Stops a systemd service systemctl stop nginx systemctl start Starts a systemd service systemctl start nginx systemctl restart Restarts a service systemctl restart nginx systemctl status Displays status of a service systemctl status nginx systemctl enable Enables service to start at boot systemctl enable nginx systemctl disable Disables service from starting at boot systemctl disable nginx systemctl mask Masks a service (prevents start) systemctl mask nginx

🕒 Scheduling Services

Command Description Example cron Background daemon to run scheduled tasks (service runs crontab jobs automatically) crontab Manages scheduled jobs for users crontab -e at Runs a job at a specific time (one-time) echo "shutdown -h now"

🧠 Process Management — Kill Signals

Signal Description Example SIGTERM Gracefully stop a process (default) kill -15 SIGKILL Forcefully kill a process kill -9 SIGHUP Hangup, often restarts a process kill -1

📋 Listing Processes and Open Files

Command Description Example top Displays real-time system processes top ps Lists active processes ps aux lsof Lists open files lsof -i :80 htop Interactive process viewer (like top) htop

🎯 Setting Priorities

Command Description Example nice Launches a process with a priority nice -n 10 myscript.sh renice Changes priority of running process renice -n 5 -p 1234

🔄 Process States

State Description Example Scenario Zombie Process completed but not cleaned up Process shows in ps output Sleeping Process waiting for an event/resource ps shows "S" state Running Currently executing ps shows "R" state Stopped Execution has been stopped ps shows "T" state

🛠️ Job Control

Command Description Example bg Resume a suspended job in background bg %1 fg Bring background job to foreground fg %1 jobs List active background jobs jobs Ctrl+Z Suspend current foreground process (press while app is running) Ctrl+C Kill current foreground process (press during command) Ctrl+D Signal end-of-input or logout (press in terminal)

🧩 Process IDs and Matching

Command Description Example pgrep Finds process IDs by name pgrep nginx pkill Kills process by name pkill -9 apache2 pidof Gets the PID of a running program pidof sshd

docs.title: 📡 Networking tools or configuration files
docs.text:
🌐 Interface Management — iproute2 Tools

Command Description Example ip View and manipulate routing, devices ip addr show ss View socket statistics (replacement for netstat) ss -tuln

🔧 Interface Management — NetworkManager

Command Description Example nmcli Command-line tool for NetworkManager nmcli device status

🧰 Interface Management — net-tools

Command Description Example ifconfig View or configure network interfaces ifconfig eth0 ifcfg Configure network scripts (legacy) vi /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0 hostname Display or set system hostname hostnamectl set-hostname server1 arp Display ARP table arp -a route Show/manipulate routing table route -n

🗂️ /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/

Location/Command Description Example /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg- Network interface configuration files vi /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0

🌍 Name Resolution

Command/File Description Example nsswitch Configures order of name resolution sources cat /etc/nsswitch.conf /etc/resolv.conf Configures DNS servers cat /etc/resolv.conf hostnamectl Manage system hostname hostnamectl set-hostname host01 resolvectl Inspect and configure name resolution resolvectl status

📡 Name Resolution — Bind-utils

Command Description Example dig DNS lookup utility dig google.com nslookup Query Internet name servers nslookup example.com host DNS lookup tool host openai.com

🌐 WHOIS

Command Description Example whois Retrieve domain registration info whois openai.com

📊 Network Monitoring

Command Description Example tcpdump Packet capture tool tcpdump -i eth0 wireshark GUI network protocol analyzer wireshark tshark Terminal-based Wireshark tshark -i eth0 netstat Display network connections & stats netstat -tuln traceroute Track packet path traceroute google.com ping Test connectivity ping 8.8.8.8 mtr Network diagnostic tool (ping + traceroute) mtr google.com

📦 Remote Networking Tools

Command Description Example ssh Secure remote login ssh user@remote-host curl Transfer data from or to a server curl https://example.com wget Download files from the web wget https://example.com/file.txt nc Netcat – transfer or listen on sockets nc -l -p 1234 rsync Sync files and directories rsync -avz /src/ user@host:/dest/ scp Secure copy over SSH scp file.txt user@host:/home/user/

docs.title: 🪛 Build and install software
docs.text:
📦 Package Management

Command Description Example dnf Fedora/RHEL package manager sudo dnf install htop yum Legacy package manager for RHEL/CentOS sudo yum update apt Debian/Ubuntu package manager sudo apt install curl rpm Red Hat Package Manager rpm -ivh package.rpm dpkg Debian package manager backend sudo dpkg -i package.deb zypper ZYpp package manager (openSUSE) sudo zypper install git

🔐 Sandboxed Applications

Tool Description Example snapd Package and run apps in a sandbox (Ubuntu) sudo snap install vlc flatpak Framework for desktop applications flatpak install flathub org.gimp.GIMP AppImage Portable app format, no install required ./AppImage.AppImage

🔄 System Updates

Task Description Example Kernel updates Update system kernel sudo dnf update kernel Package updates Update all installed packages sudo apt upgrade

docs.title: 🧮 Manage software configurations
docs.text:
⚙️ Updating Configuration Files

Item Description Example Restart service Stop and start a service fully sudo systemctl restart sshd Reload service Reload config without stopping sudo systemctl reload nginx .rpmnew New config file created after rpm upgrade /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf.rpmnew .rpmsave Old config file saved after rpm upgrade /etc/httpd/conf/httpd.conf.rpmsave

📂 Repository Configuration Files

File/Folder Description Example /etc/apt.conf Main config for APT package manager sudo nano /etc/apt.conf /etc/yum.conf Main config for YUM package manager cat /etc/yum.conf /etc/dnf/dnf.conf Config file for DNF package manager less /etc/dnf/dnf.conf /etc/yum.repo.d Directory with YUM repo config files ls /etc/yum.repo.d/ /etc/apt/sources.list.d Directory with APT repo lists ls /etc/apt/sources.list.d/

🧩 Configure Kernel Options

Item Description Example sysctl Tool to modify kernel parameters at runtime sudo sysctl -w net.ipv4.ip_forward=1 /etc/sysctl.conf File to persist kernel parameter configs sudo nano /etc/sysctl.conf

🧰 Kernel Modules

Command Description Example lsmod List currently loaded kernel modules lsmod insmod Insert a kernel module sudo insmod dummy.ko rmmod Remove a loaded kernel module sudo rmmod dummy modprobe Add/remove modules with dependencies sudo modprobe vfat modinfo Display info about a kernel module modinfo vfat imsmod (Typo or uncommon, likely "insmod") See insmod

🔧 Configure Common System Services

Service Description Example SSH Secure Shell server sudo systemctl restart sshd Network Time Protocol Sync system clock sudo systemctl status chronyd Syslog System logging daemon sudo systemctl restart rsyslog chrony Alternative NTP daemon sudo systemctl enable chronyd

🌐 Localization

Command Description Example timedatectl Control system time and timezone timedatectl set-timezone America/New_York localectl Control system locale and keyboard localectl status

docs.title: 🚨 Purpose and use of security best practices in a Linux
docs.text:
🔐 Managing Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) Certificates

Term Description Example Public key Key used to encrypt data or verify signatures ssh-keygen -y -f id_rsa to extract public key Private key Key kept secret used to decrypt or sign ~/.ssh/id_rsa file Self-signed certificate Certificate signed by itself, not trusted by browsers openssl req -x509 -newkey rsa:4096 -keyout key.pem -out cert.pem -days 365 Digital signature Data signed with private key for authentication Signing a file using openssl dgst -sha256 -sign Wildcard certificate SSL cert valid for multiple subdomains *.example.com certificate Hashing Generating fixed-size output from input data sha256sum file.txt Certificate authorities Entities that issue and sign certificates Let's Encrypt, DigiCert

🔏 Certificate Use Cases

Use Case Description Example SSL/TLS Protocols for secure encrypted communication HTTPS websites using TLS Certificate authentication Verifying identity via certificates Client cert authentication in VPNs Encryption Protecting data confidentiality Encrypting email using S/MIME certificates

🛡️ Authentication

Term Description Example Tokens Temporary credentials for authentication OAuth access tokens Multifactor authentication (MFA) Using more than one method to verify identity Using password + SMS code Pluggable authentication modules (PAM) Framework for authentication modules /etc/pam.d/ config files System Security Services Daemon (SSSD) Provides access to remote identity/auth services sssd.conf configuration Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) Protocol for directory services Active Directory or OpenLDAP Single sign-on (SSO) Login once, access multiple services Using SAML or OAuth-based SSO

🛠️ Linux Hardening

Item Description Example Security scanning Tools to find vulnerabilities nmap, Lynis, OpenVAS Secure boot Boot process that ensures only signed kernels run Enabling Secure Boot in UEFI firmware

💾 UEFI

Item Description Example System logging configurations Setup and management of system logs Configuring rsyslog.conf or journald settings Setting default umask Default permissions for new files and folders umask 027 in /etc/profile Disabling/removing insecure services Removing or disabling vulnerable services systemctl disable telnet Enforcing password strength Policies to require strong passwords Configuring /etc/security/pwquality.conf Removing unused packages Uninstalling unnecessary software sudo apt remove package-name Tuning kernel parameters Adjusting kernel settings for security Editing /etc/sysctl.conf Securing service accounts Restricting service account privileges Locking accounts with passwd -l username Configuring General secure configuration practices Firewall rules, SELinux policies

docs.title: 🧱 Implement and configure firewalls
docs.text:
🔥 Firewall Use Cases

Use Case Description Example Open and close ports Allow or block network ports sudo firewall-cmd --add-port=8080/tcp --permanent Check current configuration View active firewall rules sudo firewall-cmd --list-all Enable/disable IP forwarding Turn on/off Internet Protocol forwarding Enable: sudo sysctl -w net.ipv4.ip_forward=1Disable: sudo sysctl -w net.ipv4.ip_forward=0

🛡️ Common Firewall Technologies

Technology Description Example firewalld Dynamic firewall daemon with zones sudo firewall-cmd --state iptables Traditional Linux firewall tool sudo iptables -L nftables Modern replacement for iptables sudo nft list ruleset Uncomplicated Firewall (UFW) User-friendly firewall for Ubuntu/Debian sudo ufw status

🔑 Key Firewall Features

Feature Description Example Zones Grouping of network interfaces/rules sudo firewall-cmd --get-zones Services Predefined sets of ports/protocols sudo firewall-cmd --list-services Stateful Tracks connection states for packets Default mode in firewalld and iptables Stateless Does not track connection states Used in some simple or specialized rules

docs.title: 🖧 configure and execute remote connectivity for system management
docs.text:
🔐 SSH Configuration Files

File Path Description Example Use /etc/ssh/sshd_config Server-side SSH configuration PermitRootLogin no /etc/ssh/ssh_config Client-side default SSH settings Host * ~/.ssh/known_hosts Stores fingerprints of known hosts Auto-updated when connecting to new servers ~/.ssh/authorized_keys Contains public keys allowed to connect via SSH Add public key to allow access ~/.ssh/config Per-user client configuration Host myserver\n HostName example.com\n User admin

🧰 SSH Commands

Command Description Example ssh-keygen Generates a public/private key pair ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 ssh-copy-id Installs your public key on a remote server ssh-copy-id user@host ssh-add Adds SSH private key to the agent ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_rsa

🔄 SSH Tunneling

Type Description Example X11 Forwarding Forwards GUI applications over SSH ssh -X user@host Port Forwarding Maps a local port to a remote port ssh -L 8080:localhost:80 user@host Dynamic Forwarding Creates a SOCKS proxy over SSH ssh -D 1080 user@host

👤 Executing Commands as Another User

File Description Example Use /etc/sudoers Defines who can run what as root or other users Use visudo to edit safely PolicyKit rules Used for GUI apps and advanced permissions /etc/polkit-1/rules.d/

🛠️ Commands

Command Description Example sudo Runs a command with elevated privileges sudo apt update visudo Safely edit the sudoers file sudo visudo su - Switch user and load environment su - postgres pkexec Run programs with elevated privileges pkexec gedit

docs.title: 🧑‍💻 create simple shell scripts to automate common tasks.
docs.text:
🔁 Loops

Loop Type Description Example while Repeats while condition is true while [ $x -lt 5 ]; do echo $x; ((x++)); done for Iterates over a list or range for i in {1..5}; do echo $i; done until Repeats until condition is true until [ $x -ge 5 ]; do echo $x; ((x++)); done

🔀 Conditionals

Conditional Description Example if Executes block if true if [ $x -eq 5 ]; then echo "Yes"; fi case Matches patterns like switch case $var in 1) echo "One";; *) echo "Other";; esac

🔄 Shell Parameter Expansion

Concept Description Example Globbing Wildcard matching echo *.txt Brace expansion Creates multiple strings echo file{1..3}.txt → file1.txt file2.txt file3.txt

🔢 Comparisons

Type Description Example Arithmetic Compare numeric values if [ $a -lt $b ]; then echo "Less"; fi String Compare strings if [ "$a" = "$b" ]; then echo "Equal"; fi Boolean Logical comparisons if [ $a -gt 5 ] && [ $b -lt 10 ]; then echo OK; fi

🧮 Variables

Concept Description Example Variable Stores a value name="Linux" Access Use variable content echo "Hello $name"

🔍 Search and Replace / Regular Expressions

Tool Description Example sed Replace text echo "cat" | sed 's/cat/dog/' grep Search using regex grep '^a.*z$' file.txt

🔀 Standard Stream Redirection

Symbol Description Example | Pipe output to next command ls | grep ".txt" || OR logic false || echo "Fallback" > Redirect stdout (overwrite) echo "Hi" > file.txt >> Redirect stdout (append) echo "Hi" >> file.txt < Redirect input sort < file.txt << Here document cat << EOF ... EOF & Background process sleep 10 & && AND logic true && echo "Next" stderr Standard error ls notafile 2> error.log stdout Standard output echo "Hi" > output.log

📄 Here Documents

Concept Description Example Here doc Multi-line input to command cat << EOF \n text \n EOF

🚪 Exit Codes

Concept Description Example $? Stores last command's exit status echo $? after a command

🔧 Shell Built-In Commands

Command Description Example read Read user input read name; echo $name echo Print to screen echo "Hello" source Execute script in current shell source ~/.bashrc

🧰 Common Script Utilities

Utility Description Example awk Text processing tool awk '{print $1}' file.txt sed Stream editor sed 's/foo/bar/' file.txt find Search files/directories find . -name "*.sh" xargs Pass output as arguments find . -name "*.log" | xargs rm grep Search using regex grep "hello" file.txt egrep Extended grep egrep "foo|bar" file.txt tee Output and write to file echo test | tee output.txt wc Count lines, words, bytes wc -l file.txt cut Cut columns of text cut -d':' -f1 /etc/passwd tr Translate characters echo "abc" | tr 'a-z' 'A-Z' head Show first lines head -n 5 file.txt tail Show last lines tail -n 5 file.txt

🌍 Environment Variables

Variable Description Example Use $PATH Executable search paths echo $PATH $SHELL Current shell path echo $SHELL $? Exit status of last command echo $?

docs.text:
🟢 Container Management: Basic Operations

Operation Description Example Starting Start a container docker start my_container Stopping Stop a running container docker stop my_container Inspecting View container details docker inspect my_container Listing List containers docker ps -a Deploying Image Run a container from an image docker run -d nginx Connecting Connect to a running container (shell) docker exec -it my_container /bin/bash Logging View container logs docker logs my_container Exposing Ports Bind container ports to host docker run -p 8080:80 nginx

📦 Container Image Operations

Operation Description Example build Build image from Dockerfile docker build -t myimage . push Upload image to registry docker push myrepo/myimage pull Download image from registry docker pull ubuntu:20.04 list List local images docker images rmi Remove a local image docker rmi myimage

docs.text: Command/File Description Example git clone Clone a remote repository git clone https://github.com/user/repo.git git push Upload local commits to a remote repo git push origin main git pull Fetch and merge changes from the remote git pull origin main git commit Save staged changes with a message git commit -m "Fix issue #42" git add Stage files for the next commit git add . or git add index.js git checkout Switch to a branch or restore a file git checkout dev git branch List, create, or delete branches git branch new-feature git tag Create a tag for a commit git tag v1.0.0 .gitignore Specifies files/folders Git should ignore node_modules/

docs.text:

docs.title: Command  What it does
docs.text:
• mkdocs serve Preview docs live at http://127.0.0.1:8000/
  • mkdocs build Builds the updated site into the site/ folder
  • mkdocs gh-deploy Publishes your changes to GitHub Pages
  • Run on gitbash

docs.title: Workflow Summary
docs.text:
Edit your .md files in docs/

  • Update mkdocs.yml to reflect new pages
  • Run mkdocs serve to preview
  • Run git add ., git commit -m "...", git push
  • Deploy with mkdocs gh-deploy
